metadata.title: Impact of oxygen vacancy in CuO-ZnO catalysts on the selectivity of dimethyldichlorosilane monomer in the Rochow reaction

Industrial Chemistry and Energy Technology, Shenyang University of Chemical Technology, Shenyang, 110142, China Institute of Industrial Chemistry and Energy Technology Shenyang University of Chemical Technology Shenyang 110142 China Graphical abstract A close correlation between M2 selectivity and the quantities of oxygen vacancies of catalysts is observed that the appropriate concentration of oxygen vacancies on its surface can not only promote the adsorption of gaseous CH3Cl molecules, but also optimizes the electronic structure of surface CuO thereby optimizing the adsorption strength of CH3Cl, and its porous structure can accelerate the subsequent diffusion of generated Cu atoms, thus contributing to the formation of more Cu x Si active intermediate and ultimately leading to the best M2 selectivity. In metal oxides, oxygen vacancies (OV) are ubiquitous and intrinsic defects that can pronouncedly impact the physicochemical properties of the catalysts. In this work, we investigated the effect of the OV concentration in CuO-based catalysts on the performance of the Rochow reaction. A series of foamed CuO-ZnO composite catalysts with a highly porous structure were synthesized by a facile co-precipitation method, followed by hydrogen reduction at different times. When used in the Rochow reaction to synthesize dimethyldichlorosilane (M2), the CuO-ZnO-20 catalyst with an appropriate OV concentration exhibited the highest M2 selectivity at a similar Si conversion level of the other CuO-ZnO catalysts with different OV concentrations. By correlating the structure and performance of the catalysts, we found that the OV at an appropriate concentration in CuO-ZnO-20 acted as the adsorption sites for the reactant CH3Cl molecules, and generated an optimized electronic structure for surface CuO as confirmed by the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis (XPS), thereby optimizing the adsorption strength of CH3Cl and ultimately promoting the formation of alloyed CuxSi active phase. This work provides an effective strategy for designing heterogeneous catalysts with high selectivity by controlling the OV concentration in the catalysts. Keywords CuO-ZnO composites Foamed structure Rochow reaction Oxygen vacancies 1 Introduction Organosilicon materials have been widely used in the construction, electronic, and aerospace industries and as food-grade silicone rubber because of their superior properties such as corrosion resistance, biocompatibility, electrical insulation, and aging resistance, etc. [1,2] Typically, organosilicon materials are produced by the hydrolysis and polycondensation of silicone monomers, followed by the condensation of the generated oligomers [3,4]. Among many silicone monomers, dimethyldichlorosilane (CH3)2SiCl2, M2) is the most important intermediate for the manufacture of many organosilicon products [5], including silicon rubber and silicon resin [6,7]. Until now, the most cost-effective way to produce M2 is still the “direct synthesis” route discovered in the 1940s by E.G. Rochow [8,9], a heterogeneous reaction between solid silicon (Si) and gaseous chloromethane (CH3Cl) with the assistance of Cu-based catalysts to produce a variety of methylchlorosilanes, as expressed by the following scheme [10,11] (Scheme 1 ). Among all the products generated by this reaction, M2 is the most desired in the organosilane industry [12–14]. Over the past decades, many efforts have been made to develop highly efficient Cu-based catalysts to synthesize M2 with high selectivity and yield, such as SnO2-CuO nanorods [15], micro-flowers CuO [16], leaf-like Cu-O-Sn [11], honeycomb-like CuO/ZnO [17], and SnO2-CuO hollow microspheres [18]. It is found that the porous structure of Cu-based catalysts can improve the catalytic performance to some extent, and the synergistic interactions of various components in Cu-based composite catalysts are also conducive to the M2 synthesis [19]. However, it is still required to explore more efficient catalysts to improve the M2 selectivity and yield. In recent years, defect engineering has been demonstrated to be an efficient method to improve the catalytic performance of catalysts in many challenging chemical reactions, including NO oxidation [20], CO oxidation [21], electrocatalysis [22], photocatalysis [23–25]. For example, introducing oxygen vacancies (OV) or cation vacancies in catalysts [26,27] can provide abundant catalytic active sites for optimizing reactant adsorption and lowering the activation energy barrier [20,28,29]. Our recent study also demonstrated that Cu-O-Sn solid solution nanosheets containing abundant Cu vacancies exhibited an improved catalytic performance for the Rochow reaction [11]. However, the effect of OV in Cu-based catalysts on the performance of the Rochow reaction has not been fully explored. Furthermore, the direct link between the OV concentration and the catalytic performance in this reaction has not been established. In this work, we firstly synthesized the porous foam CuO-ZnO composites using a facile co-precipitation method and then intentionally tuned the OV concentrations on catalysts surface by controlling the hydrogen reduction degree to form OV [30]. When used as the catalyst to produce M2 via the Rochow reaction, the obtained CuO-ZnO composites with different OV concentrations showed different catalytic behaviors: the highest M2 selectivity was obtained on the CuO-ZnO sample with an appropriate OV concentration. The detailed structural characterizations revealed that the enhancement of M2 selectivity is mainly attributed to the generation of more adsorption sites for CH3Cl, and the electronic structure modification to surface CuO by introducing the appropriate OV concentration. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All the chemicals were analytical grade and used as received without further purification. Copper acetate (Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O), zinc acetate (Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O), terephthalic acid (C8H6O4), and N, N-dimethylformamide (C3H7NO) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., China. Both metallurgical silicon powder (99.5 wt%, 20–50 mesh) and the commercial catalyst Cu-Cu2O-CuO were provided by Zhejiang Hesheng Silicon Industry Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of CuO-ZnO catalysts The CuO-ZnO composite was prepared by a simple co-precipitation method similar to the one reported previously [31]. The synthesis process is shown in Fig. 1 . Firstly, 6.0 mmol Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O and 0.3 mmol Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O were dissolved in 100 mL C3H7NO under vigorous stirring to obtain solution A; solution B was obtained by dissolving 10 mmol C8H6O4 in 50 mL C3H7NO. Then, solution B was quickly added into solution A under stirring, and the obtained mixture was continuously stirred for 1 h. Subsequently, the precipitated solid was collected by centrifugation, washed with anhydrous ethanol and C3H7NO for three times, and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Finally, the dried solid was calcined in air at 700 °C for 2 h, and the obtained black sample was named as CuO-ZnO. The CuO-ZnO samples with different OV concentrations were obtained by further reducing CuO-ZnO at 260 °C in 5 vol. % H2/Ar for 10, 20, and 30 min, respectively, and are denoted as CuO-ZnO-10, CuO-ZnO-20, and CuO-ZnO-30. 2.3 Characterization The microscopic features of the samples were observed using a field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) (JEM-6700 F, JEOL, Japan) equipped with a liquid-nitrogen-cooled energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) detector for elemental analysis, and a high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) (JEM-F200 (cyro), JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) worked at a working voltage of 200 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a PANalytica X’Pert PRO MPD using CuKα radiation (k =1.5418 Å) at 40 kV and 40 mA from 10.0° to 90.0°. The metal content in synthesized samples was determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Perkin–Elmer Optima 5300DV, America). Prior to the measurement, 2 mg sample was dissolved in 3 mL nitric acid solution (3 M) at room temperature. After appropriate dilutions, until the element concentration became less than 100 ppm, the Cu and Zn contents in the solutions were examined. Raman spectroscopic analysis was performed on an InVia Reflex (England) with a wavelength of 532 nm. X-band electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded on a JEOL JES-RE2X electron spin resonance spectrometer at 90 K (BRUKER E500). The surface chemical composition was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis conducted on a Model VG ESCALAB 250 spectrometer (Thermo Electron, U.K.) using a nonmonochromatized AlKα X-ray radiation (hv = 1486.6 eV). The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were collected by using a Spectra GXFT-IR spectrometer in KBr pellets (0.002 g of sample and 0.2 g of KBr) with a scan number of 8 and a resolution of 4 cm−1. The reducibility of the catalysts was examined by H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) using a Quantachrome automated chemisorption analyzer (ChemBET pulsar TPR/TPD). Briefly, 50 mg of sample was loaded into a quartz U-tube and heated from room temperature to 200 °C at 10 °C min−1, and maintained for 1 h in Ar flow to remove moisture and impurities. The sample was then cooled to room temperature and followed by heating to 700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a binary gas mixture (10 vol. % H2/Ar) with a gas flow rate of 30 mL min−1. H2 consumption was detected as a function of increasing temperature using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.4 Catalytic measurement The evaluation of catalysts was carried out on a typical lab fixed-bed reactor following our previous report [32]. 10.0 g of silicon powder was homogeneously mixed with 0.5 g of the prepared catalysts to form a contact mass and loaded into the glass reactor. The reactor system was initially purged with purified N2 for 0.5 h followed by heating to 325 °C within 1 h under a N2 gas flow (25 mL min−1). Subsequently, N2 was switched off, and CH3Cl gas with a flow rate of 25 mL min−1 was introduced into the reactor and stopped after running for 24 h. The gas product was condensed to the liquid phase with the circulator bath controlled at −5 °C by a programmable thermal circulator (GDH series, Ningbo Xinzhi Biological Technology Co., LTD). Quantitative analysis of the products by gas chromatography (Agilent Technologies GC-7890A, KB-201 column (60 m), and TCD detector) showed that the main products included methyltrichlorosilane (CH3SiCl3, M1), dimethyldichlorosilane ((CH3)2SiCl2, M2), trimethylchlorosilane ((CH3)3SiCl, M3), methyldichlorosilane (CH3SiHCl2, M1H), dimethylchlorosilane ((CH3)2SiHCl, M2H), low boiler (LB) and high boiler (HB). Si conversion and M2 selectivity are defined as follows: (1) Si conversion: C Si % = m CM,before - m CM,after m CM,before ×100 (2) M2 selectivity: S M2 % = m M2 m M1 + m M2 + m M3 + m M1H + m M2H + m LB + m HB ×100 Here, mCM,before and mCM,after in formula (1) are the weight of contact mass before and after the reaction respectively; in formula (2) m is the mass of each product (expressed as a percentage). The rate and activation energy of the Rochow reaction over all the catalysts were measured at a gas flow rate of 25 mL min−1 in the temperature range of 295−355 °C. The activation energy was calculated using the Arrhenius equation, and the reaction rate (mol (gcat h−1) was determined by the following equation: (3) Reaction rate: Rate r s i = m si,before × C si M si × 1 m cat ×t = m si,before × C si M si × m cat ×t In formula (3), mSi, before is the mass of Si before reaction; mcat. is the mass of catalysts; MSi=28.1 g mol−1; CSi is the conversion of Si; t is the reaction time. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts 3.1.1 SEM observation Fig. 2 shows the SEM images of all the samples. It is seen that the as-synthesized CuO-ZnO had a loosely foamy structure with a size of about 60 μm (Fig. 2a). The magnified image (Fig. 2a1) revealed that the foam consisted of many spherical particles of 1 μm, forming a large number of irregular holes on the surface. Upon an H2-treatment for different times, the obtained samples still maintained the foamy structure (Fig. 2b, 2c, and 2d), and there were still a lot of holes on the surface (Fig. 2b1, 2c1, and 2d1), indicating its high structural stability. The elemental distribution of the CuO-ZnO-20 sample was determined by SEM mapping analysis, showing that O, Cu, and Zn elements were uniformly distributed in the whole foam (Fig. 3 a-e). The corresponding EDS spectrum (Fig. 3f) further confirms the presence of Zn and Cu elements, and the Cu/Zn molar ratio was consistent with the feeding ratio of the two precursors. 3.1.2 HRTEM observation Fig. 4 shows the HRTEM images of the CuO-ZnO sample. As displayed, the intimate contact interface of the highly crystallized CuO and ZnO phases were clearly seen. At both sides of the interface, the lattice spacings of 0.252 nm and 0.247 nm were indexed to the (111) crystal plane of the monoclinic CuO and the (101) crystal plane of the hexagonal ZnO, respectively. Furthermore, the two crystal planes were aligned almost in parallel. This intimate contact interface formed by CuO and ZnO nanoparticles should be able to facilitate the electron transfer, thereby generating the so-called electronic synergetic effect. 3.1.3 XRD analysis Fig. 5 shows the XRD patterns of all the samples. In all cases, the diffraction peaks at 2θ of 32.5°, 35.5°, 38.7°, 48.7°, 53.4°, 58.2°, 61.5°, 66.2°, 68.1°, 72.3°, and 75.2° are indexed to (110), (11−1), (111), (20−2), (020), (202), (31−3), (220), (311) and (22−2) crystal planes of the monoclinic CuO (JCPDS No. 48-1548) respectively, and those at 2θ of 31.7°, 34.4°, 36.2°, 47.5°, and 56.6° to the (100), (002), (101), (102), and (110) crystal planes of the hexagonal ZnO (JCPDS No. 36-1451), respectively. There was no detection of any other impurities or phases. The sharp diffraction lines in all the patterns confirmed the good crystallinity of these samples. Nevertheless, compared with that of CuO-ZnO, the crystallinity degree of the CuO-ZnO-x was slightly lower due to the introduction of OV, which will be analyzed further in the following section. Moreover, the Zn/Cu molar ratios of all the samples measured by ICP-OES were in good agreement with the feed ratios of the two precursors (not shown). 3.1.4 Raman and EPR analysis Raman spectra can provide additional information on OV [33]. Fig. 6 a presents the Raman spectra of all the samples. There are two Raman peaks at 290 and 790 cm−1 for all the samples ascribed to the typical Raman vibration modes of CuO [19]. Compared with those of CuO-ZnO, the Raman bands of CuO-ZnO-x obviously became wider and less symmetric with increasing the reduction time, implying the non-stoichiometric structure, or partial destruction of Cu-O bond in the samples, which is most likely caused by the formation of OV [34]. The EPR spectra of CuO-ZnO and CuO-ZnO-x (Fig. 6b) showed that all the samples exhibited a strong signal peak at g = 2.003, which corresponds to the surface OV [34]. And the peak intensity followed the sequence of CuO-ZnO-30 > CuO-ZnO-20 > CuO-ZnO-10 > CuO-ZnO, confirming the generation of different OV concentrations by adjusting the time of hydrogen reduction [30]. 3.1.5 XPS analysis Fig. 7 shows the XPS spectra of Cu 2p, Zn 2p, and O 1s for all the samples. There exist two kinds of oxygen peaks in the O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 7a) for all the samples. The first peak centered at 531.8–532.5 eV (marked as OA) is ascribed to the chemisorbed oxygen, while the second peak at 529.4–529.7 eV (marked as OL) represents the lattice O in Cu–O [19]. Obviously, for the CuO-ZnO-x samples, the OL shifted towards the low binding energy direction with the increase of the reduction time compared with that of CuO-ZnO, implying that the electron density around O2− was increased. In Cu 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 7b), the Cu 2p3/2 peak lay in the range of 933.2–934.1 eV, accompanying with two obvious satellite peaks (marked by Sat.) at 943.1 and 961.5 eV, confirming the presence of Cu2+ [35]. It is clear that with the increasing reduction time, a slight shift toward the high values of the binding energies could also be observed, suggesting the electron density around Cu was gradually decreased. As shown in Fig. 7c, the binding energies of Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2 in the Zn 2p spectra are located at 1021.4 and 1044.5 eV, respectively, which are in agreement with the previously reported values for Zn2+ [19]. Furthermore, the binding energy of Zn2+ showed the same change trend as that of Cu2+, suggesting the decrease of electron density around Zn as well. The above results confirm that due to the OV introduction, the electronic structures of Cu2+, Zn2+, and O2− were modified. These changes can be explained as follows: part of electrons was transferred from Cu and Zn to the lattice oxygen through the formed CuO-ZnO interfaces, causing the increase of the electron density around O2- at the expense of the electron density around Cu and Zn. 3.1.6 H2-TPR analysis Fig. 8 shows the H2-TPR profiles of all the samples. It can be seen that all the samples have only one wide reduction peak in the temperature range of 250−400 °C, which corresponds to the reduction of copper oxide to metallic copper [36]. As indicated by the dotted lines in the figure, the initial reduction peak and maximum reduction peak of the obtained CuO-ZnO-x samples progressively shifted to high temperatures with the increase of reduction time. This shift is because the formed oxygen vacancy in CuO-ZnO-x samples could capture the electrons from Cu2+ and Zn2+, making the release of the oxygen atoms more difficult. This observation is consistent with the above results of hydrogen reduction at different times. 3.2 Catalytic performances of the catalysts Table 1 summarizes the catalytic results of the Rochow reaction on the catalyst samples at 325 °C for 24 h. As displayed, CuO-ZnO gave a M2 selectivity of 74.2% and Si conversion of 10%. After introducing OV, a higher M2 selectivity was obtained on CuO-ZnO-x samples at the same Si conversion level of CuO-ZnO. And their M2 selectivity follows the order of CuO-ZnO-20 > CuO-ZnO-30 > CuO-ZnO-10. Notably, CuO-ZnO-20 achieved a M2 selectivity of 83.7% at a Si conversion level of 12.3%, higher than those obtained on CuO-ZnO-30 (M2 selectivity of 78% at a Si conversion of 10%) and CuO-ZnO-10 (M2 selectivity of 75.3% at a Si conversion of 9%). These results demonstrate that the OV played an important role in the improvement of M2 selectivity. Moreover, it is found that the catalytic performance of the commercial catalyst Cu-Cu2O-CuO is also inferior to that of our best-performing CuO-ZnO-20 catalyst. As exhibited in Fig. 9 a, in all cases, the M2 selectivity increased with the reaction temperature up to 325 °C. It then decreased again at higher temperatures because the Rochow reaction is exothermic, which thermodynamically favors low reaction temperatures. A continuous increase in Si conversion was observed in the entire reaction process for all the samples (Fig. 9b), and among them, CuO-ZnO-20 showed the fastest reaction rate (Fig. 9c). Furthermore, the measured apparent activation energy (Ea) values of Cu-Zn, Cu-Zn-10, Cu-Zn-20 and Cu-Zn-30 were 183.8, 136.3, 126.3 and 129.4 kJ mol−1, respectively (Fig. 9d). In agreement with the catalytic results, Cu-Zn-20 had the lowest Ea value. Obviously, Ov in CuO-ZnO catalysts has great impact on the activation energy. 3.3 Structure-performance relationship and catalytic reaction mechanism As previously reported [11,19,20], the Cu x Si species, formed by the diffusion of Cu into the Si lattice, is the real active phase for M2 production in the Rochow reaction. Thus, we further performed FT-IR measurements on the spent contact masses (unreacted residue) after a 24 h reaction to detect the formation of Cu x Si in our study. As shown in Fig. 10 , in all cases, four bands could be observed. The weak bands at ∼2920 and ∼2960 cm−1 correspond to the symmetric (Vs(CH3)) and asymmetric (Vas(CH3)) C–H stretching vibrations in the CH3 group [37], respectively, confirming the dissociative adsorption of CH3Cl on the surface of the contact masses, which is the key step to generate the Cu x Si active phase, as revealed in our previous studies [38]. Indeed, there appeared a strong band at 1045 cm−1 corresponding to the vibration of Si–O–Si, which is ascribed to the alloying reaction between Cu and Si at 325 °C [39], indicating the formation of Cu x Si species. Obviously, with the increase of reduction time, the Si–O–Si band (Vs(Si-O-Si)) gradually increased in intensity for the treated samples, suggesting a gradual increase in the amount of Cu x Si. It is also noted that the weak band at 1275 cm−1 corresponding to the ρ(CH3) mode exhibited the same trend as the Si-O-Si mode in intensity, indicating the adsorption of CH3Cl was continuously enhanced. As we know, too strong or too weak adsorption of reactant molecules is adverse to their subsequent activation. Therefore, although the maximum amount of the Cu x Si active phase was formed on the CuO-ZnO-30 sample, the subsequent activation of CH3Cl with Si was suppressed because of its too strong adsorption, eventually leading to a decrease in the catalytic activity. On the contrary, in the case of CuO-ZnO-20, the amount of Cu x Si formed was slightly less than that of CuO-ZnO-30; however, its moderate CH3Cl adsorption greatly promoted the reaction of CH3Cl with Si in Cu x Si, which ultimately led to higher activity. Many reports have proven that OV can act as the adsorption and activation site of reactants [40,41]. Our previous studies also confirmed that Cu vacancy could effectively adsorb CH3Cl molecules [11,20]. Thus, it will not be strange in the present system that OV plays the same role and serves as the adsorption site for CH3Cl. Therefore, we can reasonably conclude that the superior catalytic performance of the CuO-ZnO-20 sample is attributed to the following two factors: (1) the OV can serve as the adsorption site for the reactant molecule CH3Cl; (2) the introduction of a suitable OV concentration can achieve an optimized electron density on surface CuO, which can optimize the adsorption strength of CH3Cl. These two factors can promote the formation of Cu atoms and the alloyed Cu x Si active phase, thereby enhancing the M2 selectivity and yield. In addition, the loose and porous structure should provide more contact sites with CH3Cl molecules and facilitate the mass transfer of the generated Cu atom into the Si lattice, further improving the catalytic efficiency. Based on the above analyses, a possible catalytic reaction mechanism on the best-performing CuO-ZnO-20 catalyst is proposed, as illustrated in Fig. 11 . Firstly, a small amount of catalyst is dispersed on the Si surface to form the contact mass. After the CH3Cl molecules are introduced, they are dissociated and preferentially adsorbed on the surface OV of CuO and electronically modified CuO, leading to the formation of Cu atoms through the reaction of CH3Cl with CuO. Meanwhile, at the reaction temperature, the diffusion of the formed copper atoms into the Si matrix is accelerated. As a result, the alloyed Cu x Si active phase is gradually formed at the contact interfaces of the Si and the catalysts. Finally, the CH3Cl molecules are adsorbed on the surface of Cu x Si and transformed into M2 through their reaction with Si. 4 Conclusion In summary, highly porous CuO-ZnO hybrid catalysts containing different concentrations of oxygen vacancy have been successfully prepared by a simple co-precipitation method, followed by a reduction in a hydrogen atmosphere. Among all the samples with different oxygen vacancy concentrations, the CuO-ZnO-20 catalyst exhibits the highest M2 selectivity in the Rochow reaction. A close correlation between the M2 selectivity and the catalyst oxygen vacancy concentration is revealed upon a comprehensive analysis. It is found that the appropriate concentration of oxygen vacancies can not only promote the adsorption of gaseous CH3Cl molecules but also optimizes the electronic structure of surface CuO, thereby optimizing the adsorption strength of CH3Cl. Also, the porous structure of the catalysts can accelerate the subsequent diffusion of the generated Cu atoms, thus contributing to the formation of more CuxSi active intermediate and ultimately to the highest M2 selectivity. Our work demonstrates that generating an appropriate oxygen vacancy concentration on the catalyst surface is an effective approach to improving the properties of heterogeneous catalysts. 5 Author contributions Ji Y, Su F, and Xu G conceived the idea of the project. Jiang X conducted the synthesis of catalysts. Jiang X, Li J, Zhu Y, and Kang T performed the catalyst characterizations and catalytic tests. Ji Y, Zhong Z, Su F, and Xu G analyzed the data. Jiang X, Ji Y, Zhang Z, Su F, and Xu G drafted the manuscript. All authors participated the general discussion of the manuscript. Declaration of Competing Interest The authors declare no competing financial interest. coredata.dc:description: In metal oxides, oxygen vacancies (OV) are ubiquitous and intrinsic defects that can pronouncedly impact the physicochemical properties of the catalysts. In this work, we investigated the effect of the OV concentration in CuO-based catalysts on the performance of the Rochow reaction. A series of foamed CuO-ZnO composite catalysts with a highly porous structure were synthesized by a facile co-precipitation method, followed by hydrogen reduction at different times. When used in the Rochow reaction to synthesize dimethyldichlorosilane (M2), the CuO-ZnO-20 catalyst with an appropriate OV concentration exhibited the highest M2 selectivity at a similar Si conversion level of the other CuO-ZnO catalysts with different OV concentrations. By correlating the structure and performance of the catalysts, we found that the OV at an appropriate concentration in CuO-ZnO-20 acted as the adsorption sites for the reactant CH3Cl molecules, and generated an optimized electronic structure for surface CuO as confirmed by the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis (XPS), thereby optimizing the adsorption strength of CH3Cl and ultimately promoting the formation of alloyed CuxSi active phase. This work provides an effective strategy for designing heterogeneous catalysts with high selectivity by controlling the OV concentration in the catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Impact of oxygen vacancy in CuO-ZnO catalysts on the selectivity of dimethyldichlorosilane monomer in the Rochow reaction
